column4: skutarth: that sounds like something you should tweak in BIOS...do you have mobo manual?
skutarth: otherwise, are the hard drives clean or is this multi-boot situation?
skutarth: can you reformat them or not?
skutarth:  i'm not an expert at this...internal drives formatted as RAID, correct?  is this done via mobo function or via some other os that's installed?
skutarth:  hm...i'm kind of out of ideas.  Unless I'm mistaken, the mobo should present the RAID drives as a single device entity to software os -- or at least i think so
skutarth: but my knowledge gets really thin at this point...

skutarth:  if drivers required, i think you are SOL.  another drive would probably do it -- and i'd be willing to be you won't be able to access the RAID that's in there unless by miracle you find the right drivers
skutarth:  drives are very cheap now -- especially if you just need 200GB SATA...they're like $40
can anyone tell me if there are source files or other stuff left over from my original "apt-get install php5" ?? if so, where would i find them?
sources are in separate packages.
i'm just trying to find out what ./configure options they used to build php5
any ideas?  it's usually visible in phpinfo output but not in Ubuntu's build
Download the source package and read the scripts in the debian directory then.

skutarth: hard t say there...i think Ubuntu installer will try to move the boot.ini or create one if it can't find the windows 7 boot.ini.  If Ubuntu doesn't understand the fakeRAID format, then it will probably assume the drives are not formatted

any idea where i might download those?  I'm quite unfamiliar with the structure of debian packages.  also, you think the configure command might be all in one place?  or would i need to parse out an entire long file?
apt-get source php5.  Look in debian/rules in particular.
skutarth:  the only way you are likely to learn the truth here is the hard way...are you prepared to reinstall win 7 if it ruins everything?  if not, i wouldn't try it.
tonyyaruso:  you are the dude... thanks.  where does this put the package on my file system?
current working directory
(and don't use sudo)
less you friendly soul.  thanks
np
yikes!  that rules file is beastly
